articles.headline: The Volt, G.M.’s Plug-In Car, Gets a $41,000 Price Tag
articles.snippet: The carmaker has begun taking orders for the plug-in vehicle, which is expected to be at dealers in November.
articles.abstract: The carmaker has begun taking orders for the plug-in vehicle, which is expected to be at dealers in November.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  General Motors on Tuesday put the base price of its Chevrolet Volt, a plug-in car capable of driving about 40 miles on battery power without using gasoline, at $41,000 before a $7,500 federal tax credit.

articles.headline: Tobacco Funds Shrink as Obesity Fight Intensifies
articles.snippet: As public health priorities shift, anti-tobacco programs are losing out to the campaign against obesity.
articles.abstract: As public health priorities shift, anti-tobacco programs are losing out to the campaign against obesity.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation decided in 1991 to take on Joe Camel, it became the nation’s largest private funding source for fighting smoking. The foundation spent $700 million to help knock the cartoon character out of advertisements, finance research and advocacy for higher cigarette taxes and smoke-free air laws and, ultimately, to aid in reducing the nation’s smoking rate almost by half.

articles.headline: Ex-Regulators Get Set to Lobby on New Financial Rules
articles.snippet: Corporations are recruiting former regulators to help negotiate an avalanche of anticipated federal rules.
articles.abstract: Corporations are recruiting former regulators to help negotiate an avalanche of anticipated federal rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As the battle over toughened financial restrictions moves to a new front, the regulatory agencies that will create hundreds of new rules for the nation’s banks will face a lobbying blitz from companies intent on softening the blow. And many of the lobbyists the regulators hear from will be their former colleagues.

articles.headline: Wind Drives Growing Use of Batteries
articles.snippet: Utilities are developing storage batteries to smooth the flow of intermittent sources of power, like wind farms.
articles.abstract: Utilities are developing storage batteries to smooth the flow of intermittent sources of power, like wind farms.
articles.lead_paragraph: The rapid growth of wind farms, whose output is hard to schedule reliably or even predict, has the nation’s electricity providers scrambling to develop energy storage to ensure stability and improve profits.

articles.headline: Democrats Split as House Backs War Funds
articles.snippet: The House approved a war funding bill, but Democrats splintered after a disclosure of battlefield documents.
articles.abstract: The House approved a war funding bill, but Democrats splintered after a disclosure of battlefield documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives agreed on Tuesday to provide $37 billion to continue financing America’s two wars, but the vote showed deepening divisions and anxiety among Democrats over the course of the nearly nine-year-old conflict in Afghanistan.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: On the Surface, Gulf Oil Spill Is Vanishing Fast; Concerns Stay
articles.snippet: The oil is clearing much faster than expected, but concern remains over the unseen effects.
articles.abstract: The oil is clearing much faster than expected, but concern remains over the unseen effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: The oil slick in the Gulf of Mexico appears to be dissolving far more rapidly than anyone expected, a piece of good news that raises tricky new questions about how fast the government should scale back its response to the Deepwater Horizon disaster.
articles.byline: By Justin Gillis and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: BP’s Blueprint for Emerging From Crisis
articles.snippet: The company’s latest moves show how it hopes to continue to compete on an equal footing with the world’s top producers.
articles.abstract: The company’s latest moves show how it hopes to continue to compete on an equal footing with the world’s top producers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BP said on Tuesday that it had set aside $32.2 billion to pay for the biggest offshore oil spill in United States history.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: The Case for $320,000 Kindergarten Teachers
articles.snippet: A new study found students with better teachers learned more in kindergarten — and earned more as young adults.
articles.abstract: A new study found students with better teachers learned more in kindergarten — and earned more as young adults.
articles.lead_paragraph: How much do your kindergarten teacher and classmates affect the rest of your life?

articles.headline: Videos Rouse Russian Anger Toward Police
articles.snippet: An insider account of the culture of corruption in the nation’s police forces has been viewed more than two million times.
articles.abstract: An insider account of the culture of corruption in the nation’s police forces has been viewed more than two million times.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOVOROSSIYSK, Russia  One day last fall, a police officer here put on his uniform and sat on a drab tan couch before a video camera. In a halting monotone, he recorded two video appeals to Vladimir V. Putin, 13 minutes in all.
